awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Dynamics and Predictability of East and Central Pacific El Nino/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) Events
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impacts of this collaborative project include furthering understanding of different types of El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events and their predictability, and the training of two graduate students, This project will further our understanding of the dynamics and predictability of Central Pacific  and East Pacific  ENSO events. The research team has extensive experience in using observational constrained approaches as well as in undertaking simulations using a suite of physical models. 

The following scientific questions will be addressed: What dynamical processes are responsible for the evolution of  initial structures into a particular type of ENSO event? Are there physical mechanisms that can explain the stochastic forcing of these initial structures? How do initial structures and stochastic forcing throughout the evolution of a particular event affect the predictability of a particular type of ENSO event? How important - and how predictable - are changes in mean state conditions versus changes in stochastic forcing in influencing long-term variations in the statistics of different types of ENSO events?

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the processes that generate climate variations associated with the El Niño / Southern Oscillation (ENSO) phenomenon in the tropical Pacific. ENSO is the most prominent source of year-to-year climate variability on Earth and is a major source of predictability in the climate system. The project focused on processes that produce ENSO events with different spatial characteristics, notably events with sea surface temperature structures that are dominant in the central or eastern Pacific (CP or EP events; this is often referred to as ENSO diversity). Understanding whether, and why, CP and EP ENSO characteristics are predictable provides important information for climate prediction on seasonal to multi-year time scales.

This project advanced understanding of ENSO variability by (1) advancing theoretical understanding of ocean / atmosphere interactions in the tropics; (2) developing new statistical / empirical models of tropical Pacific ocean / atmosphere interaction that can be used to analyze or predict ENSO; and (3) testing findings from the empirical models using full physics-based coupled climate models. One of the most significant achievements of this project is the successful use of both statistical / empirical methods and physical modeling side-by-side as two complimentary techniques for understanding ENSO diversity.

Development of pure theory provided an explanation for how and why mid-latitude precursors to ENSO events (referred to as meridional modes) evolve toward the equatorial region and influence ENSO events with central Pacific characteristics. This project developed a new theoretical model of ocean / atmosphere interaction that provides an alternate and more realistic explanation for the structure and evolution of these meridional modes.

The statistical / empirical models that were used and developed in this project provided new methods for analyzing and predicting ENSO events. These models used a technique called linear inverse modeling (LIM) in which a dynamical model is derived from the statistics of a system itself. These models provide estimates of the predictable dynamics of a system, as well as the statistics of the unpredictable processes that force those dynamics. This project used a standard linear inverse model (also LIM) to characterize the spatial and temporal structure of the predictable and unpredictable components of ENSO event evolution, providing guidance as to what specific processes are responsible for generating ENSO diversity for individual historical events. We also developed a form of LIM with seasonally varying statistics that will be especially useful for predicting and analyzing ENSO events in future studies.

One limitation of a standard LIM is that by construction, it must produce output (such as the evolution of an ENSO event) with Gaussian statistics (e.g. symmetric amplitude and duration of ENSO events). However, observed ENSO variability, and ENSO diversity, show subtle but important deviations from Gaussianity. This project developed a method for estimating a new type of LIM in which the statistics of the unpredictable forcing are influenced by state of the system itself (this is in line with what we know about the observed ENSO system). To our knowledge, this specific type of model has never been developed. We showed that observed ENSO variability, especially asymmetry in amplitude and duration, is consistent with such a model. This is a major advance and provides a null hypothesis for ENSO asymmetry.

One of the important results from this work is that the physical relationships that were identified using statistical / empirical models were tested using physics-based numerical models. We used two models with limited physics - one with physics to simulate meridional modes but not ENSO, and the other that simulates ENSO but not meridional modes - to show that evolution of meridional modes can lead to the development of ENSO, as seen in observations and in the statistical / empirical models. We analyzed how these two types of tropical variability interact, illuminating some features of ENSO diversity. Analysis of the statistical / empirical models also provided insight into the types of unpredictable forcing mechanisms that influence ENSO events. We applied these forcing structures in a coupled model framework and reproduced the evolution of ENSO events with central or east Pacific characteristics.

Finally, this project contributed to twelve peer-reviewed papers, three Ph.D. Dissertations, a number of public talks, and training of three graduate students and one undergraduate student. The project also included opportunities for the graduate students to spend time at NOAA Earth System Research Laboratories, which provided excellent broadening experiences for the students.
